title: AMC-8
text:
AMC-8, also known as Aurora III, previously GE-8, is a <a href="C%20band%20%28IEEE%29">C-band</a> <a href="satellite">satellite</a> located at 139° West, covering the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a> and the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>. It is owned and operated by <a href="SES%20World%20Skies">SES World Skies</a>, formerly <a href="SES%20Americom">SES Americom</a> and before that <a href="SES%20Americom">GE Americom</a>. The satellite provides critical telecommunications services to <a href="AT%26amp%3BT%20Alascom">AT&T Alascom</a>, which occupies most of the satellite's capacity. AMC-8 was launched in 2000 as GE-8, and replaced Satcom-C5 in March 2001.
AMC-8 was used by thousands of terrestrial radio stations for network feeds using ground equipment from Starguide, X-Digital Systems, Wegener and International Datacasting. Major tenants were Cumulus Media Networks Satellite Services (which includes <a href="Citadel%20Media">Citadel Media</a>, <a href="Talk%20Radio%20Network">Talk Radio Network</a>, <a href="WOR%20Radio%20Network">WOR Radio Network</a> and others), Skyview Networks (which includes ABC News, ABC Radio, California News Network, Arizona News Network, numerous Professional and Collegian Sports networks, and others), Orbital Media Networks (which includes <a href="United%20Stations%20Radio%20Networks">United Stations Radio Networks</a>, <a href="John%20Tesh">John Tesh</a>, and others), <a href="Premiere%20Radio%20Networks">Premiere Radio Networks</a>, <a href="Dial%20Global">Dial Global</a>, <a href="Westwood%20One%20%281976%E2%80%932011%29">Westwood One</a>, Learfield Communications, <a href="The%20Free%20Beer%20and%20Hot%20Wings%20Show">The Free Beer and Hot Wings Show</a> (Transponder 15), and others. However, these were moved over to another satellite, <a href="AMC-18">AMC-18</a>. Audio network transmissions on AMC-8 ended as of midnight 30 June 2017. Since AMC-8 is past its design life, it will soon be decommissioned. As of 1 July 2017, there are no plans to put another satellite in AMC-8's orbital slot (139° West).
It carries 24 36 <a href="Hertz">MHz</a> <a href="C%20band%20%28IEEE%29">C-band</a> <a href="Transponder%20%28satellite%20communications%29">transponders</a>, with 20 <a href="Watt">watts</a> SSPA amplifiers. Its amplifier redundancy is 16 for 12, and its receiver redundancy is four for two. It carries two beacons, one broadcasting on a horizontal frequency of 3700.5 MHz, and the other on a vertical frequency of 4199.5 MHz.
